Impact of support on the catalytic behavior of Mo/γ-Al2O3 and Mo/MgO catalysts on the desulfurization reaction M. Soltanieh A. Heidarinasab M. Ardjmand H. Ahmadpanahi Morteza Bahmani ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemical Engineering Science and Research Branch Islamic Azad University Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This study uses the Taguchi method to evaluate the impact of support on the catalytic behavior of Mo/MgO and Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts through the parametric effects on the kinetics of dibenzothiophene desulfurization reaction. The parameters studied were contact time, temperature, activation temperature, reaction gas type, sulfur concentration, pressure, and nitrogen concentration. Some discrepancies existed in the order of significance of the reaction parameters between the two catalysts. The compensation phenomena revealed a change in the reaction mechanism with temperature for Mo/MgO catalyst that approximates that of Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at higher temperatures. Transition state theory showed that for the Mo/MgO catalyst, the tight activation transition state mode is replaced with a loose mode at higher temperatures, whereas for the Mo/γ-Al2O3catalyst, the loose mode prevails across the entire temperature range studied. Furthermore, some temperature-dependent concentrations of SH and OH functional groups were detected at the catalyst surface, profoundly influencing the adsorption of the reactants and the inhibition effect of pyridine. Keywords Taguchi method Desulfurization Dibenzothiophene Compensation effect Transition state theory Parametric effects 1 Introduction Supported molybdenum (Mo)-based catalysts are well established in the hydrotreatment of petroleum fractions [1–3]. Such catalysts have attracted a great deal of attention based on their use in upgrading oil products [4]. In the petroleum refining industry and particularly from a commercial point of view, preparing and developing catalysts with high activity and high stability is of great interest for improving the performance of the desulfurization process. Preparing an effective catalyst requires knowledge about the origins of the different functions of the catalyst and the dependence of those functions on the nature of the support, its composition, and other variables. The support plays an important role in determining the activity of the supported catalytic phase [5–8] and can significantly influence the catalytic characteristics. Various supports have been used for desulfurization reactions, including single and mixed metal oxides [8], carbon [9,10], and zeolites [11,12]. In addition, most of the supports studied thus far have been acidic in nature, and a direct relationship has been found between the acidity of the support and its activity [8,13]. However, studies have indicated that alkaline MgO is as active as (or sometimes even more active than) acidic supports [14]. In addition, the higher resistance of MgO supported catalysts to coking may facilitate operation at low or moderate pressures. There is therefore interest in the influence of an alkaline support such as MgO on the activity of a catalyst. In a previous study (unpublished to date), we compared the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction mechanism on Mo/γ-Al2O3 and Mo/MgO catalysts and found a strong dependence between the reaction mechanism and the nature of the support. The γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst facilitated the reaction primarily through the hydrogenative pathway, while the reaction on the MgO supported catalyst proceeded through the direct desulfurization pathway. Moreover, these different pathways were attributed to the dissimilar Mo phases that emerged over the different supports (the sulfide and oxide Mo phases over the γ-Al2O3 and MgO supports, respectively). Therefore, the present study attempts to evaluate the influences of the support on the catalytic activity of two catalysts (Mo/MgO and Mo/γ-Al2O3) in response to different desulfurization reaction parameters through the parametric effects on the kinetics of the reaction. The effect of the reaction parameters on the kinetics of the desulfurization reaction has been extensively studied for γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts (for example [15–17]). There are also some publications, concerning MgO as a support for this reaction [18–23]. However, these studies have typically used one-factor-at-a-time (OFAT) experiments. The multiple effective parameters and the possible interactions between them, necessitate the use of statistically designed experiments. Nonetheless, statistical design of experiments (DOE) offers substantial gains with respect to time efficiency and scientific insight [24]. In this study, the Taguchi approach [25,26], a standard statistical techniques, is applied to evaluate the relative significance and contributions of the parameters to the kinetics of the desulfurization reaction on the two supported Mo-based catalysts. In addition, compensation phenomena and transition state theory (TST), along with some experimental surface techniques, are used to investigate the mechanisms of the reaction over these catalysts. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Design of experiments The Taguchi method is an effective DOE approach that can simultaneously determine the impacts of several factors while significantly minimizing the costs and time of experiments [27]. Selection of control factors is an important step in the Taguchi approach and control factors are generally set by the experimenter based upon the experimenter's experience. Temperature, contact time, activation temperature, sulfur concentration, pressure, and concentration of any nitrogen-containing compound are among the most important factors influencing catalytic desulfurization processes [15–17,28,29]. Generally, this reaction is performed in the presence of hydrogen; accordingly, the effect of reaction gas type (H2 or N2) has been introduced as a new variable. Moreover, an empty column was assigned as an extra variable to define the residual errors. All of these factors were selected as input variables and their impacts were investigated on sulfur conversion (XS) as the response variable. Four levels were selected for temperature and contact time; two levels were selected for the other variables (Table 1 ). In the Taguchi statistical method, different special designs named “orthogonal arrays” are used to study the entire parameter space [30]. In this study, a mixed-level L16 orthogonal array was chosen to determine the parametric effects on XS over two catalysts (Mo/MgO and Mo/γ-Al2O3). Coded data were used in Taguchi's L16 experimental design (Table 2 ). In addition, five extra experiments beyond those used in the DOE were performed to verify the predictive reliability of this approach. The deviation between the desired and the experimental values, which requires the determination of the signal-to-noise (SN) ratio, was evaluated using a loss function [31]. In this study, the larger-is-better approach was chosen, as this process was designed to determine the higher sulfur conversion. The SN-ratio for the characteristics evaluated using this larger-is-better approach was calculated using Eq. (1) as follows: (1) S N = − 10 log 10 ( 1 n ∑ ⁣ 1 y i 2 ) where n is the number of observations under the same experimental conditions and y is the measured result for sulfur conversion. The optimization process and required calculations were performed using version 15 of the Minitab software package (Minitab, State College, Pennsylvania, US) [32] and Microsoft Excel 2007 (Microsoft; Redmond, Washington, USA). 2.2 Catalysts MgO was prepared by dehydration of Mg(OH)2 (Merck) at 800°C under static air. (Unpublished findings from our previous studies demonstrated that the method of MgO preparation influences both the behavior and the activity of the catalyst. Therefore, the aforementioned procedure is strongly recommended for duplication of the present study.) Highly acidic γ-Al2O3 +3wt% P2O5 (noted γ-Al2O3) was prepared using the sol-gel method as described elsewhere [33]. These supports were then impregnated with Mo (10%) by the incipient wetness technique using aqueous solution containing the required amount of ammonium hepta molybdate (BDH). The impregnated catalysts were dried at 120°C for 24h and then calcined for 4h in air at 550°C and 400°C for MgO and γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts, respectively. The catalysts were ground to pass through a 100-mesh screen (US sieve series) before use in reaction tests. The textural properties and Mo content of the catalysts are reported in Table 3 . 2.3 Reaction tests The activities of the catalysts for dibenzothiophene (DBT) desulfurization reactions were evaluated in a fixed bed reactor at different reaction conditions (Table 1). The catalysts were activated for 8h under a flow of dimethyl disulfide (1% in isooctane) and H2 at different temperatures (Table 1). During each run, 0.1g of the catalyst was loaded into the reactor, with glass wool used as a diluent. DBT (Merck) and pyridine (Merck) were dissolved in isooctane (Ubichem) to yield the respective concentrations of sulfur and nitrogen. The products were analyzed for total sulfur content using Antek (PAC; Houston, Texas, USA). 2.4 Characterization of the catalysts X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the catalysts were carried out under inert atmosphere using a VG ESCALAB spectrophotometer (VG Systems Inc.; Renton, Washington, USA) equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV). During the measurement, the base pressure of the system was around 10−10 mbar. C 1s (248.6eV) was used as the reference to correct the binding energy. Data processing (acquisition, subtraction of the background, and decomposition) was carried out using the XPS processing software. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was recorded with a 4cm−1 resolution on a JASCO FT/IR-4100 equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory and a TGC detector (JASCO Analytical Instruments; Easton, Maryland, USA). Self-supporting pellets of pure powder catalysts were connected to a conventional gas-manipulation evacuation line and pretreated for 1h at 350°C under vacuum condition (10−10 mbar), followed by adsorption of DBT (5% in isooctane) at 100°C, and evacuation at 200°C, 300°C, and 350°C, after which a spectrum was recorded. The nature of the specific chemical groups of the self-supporting pellets of spent catalysts was also determined by FT-IR experiments at room temperature without any pretreatment. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired at room temperature on an Equinox-2000 (INEL; Artenay, France) X-ray diffractometer utilizing Cu Kα radiation (k=1.5418Å) in a Bragg-Brentano geometry. The incident beam was focused on the sample through a programmable slit to ensure a constant irradiation length of about 10mm on the sample. The diffracted beam was directed through an anti-scattering programmable slit, a 0.2mm reception slit, and a (002) graphite monochromator before reaching the punctual detector. About 500mg of powder was prepared in a rotating sample holder. The accelerating voltage and applied current were 40kV and 30mA, respectively. The specific surface area, pore volume, and porosity distribution of the catalysts were obtained from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, determined at 77K with an ASAP 2010 apparatus (Micrometrics). Surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distribution and total pore volume were determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Prior to adsorption, the samples were out-gassed at 300°C for 4h under a residual pressure of 10−10 mbar. Elemental analyses of Mo content in the acid-digested catalysts were performed using atomic absorption spectroscopy with a contrAA 700 (Analytik Jena AG; Jena, Germany). 3 Results 3.1 Effect of reaction parameters on desulfurization reactions: Taguchi approach In this study, XS is treated as the response factor. The parametric effects on XS for different catalysts (Mo/MgO and Mo/γ-Al2O3) are evaluated through SN-ratio and range analysis. 3.1.1 SN-ratio analysis Maximum elimination of sulfur is desirable in desulfurization reactions where XS should be maximized. Therefore, Taguchi analysis is carried out using ‘larger-is-better’ SN-ratio as represented by Eq. (1). The plots of the main effects on the SN-ratio obtained with two different catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The plots indicate that XS increases as the reaction contact time, total pressure, and sulfur concentration increase. Replacing hydrogen with nitrogen as the reaction gas and introducing the pyridine as a poisonous nitrogen-containing compound have negative effects on sulfur conversion. Increasing the activation temperature led to slight improvement on conversion on the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, while conversion remained nearly constant on the MgO supported catalyst. Increasing the temperature accelerates the reaction on the Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. However, the conversion on the MgO supported catalyst declines at lower temperatures (below 320°C) and increases at higher temperatures. Residual error leads to a small statistical effect in the empty column (Fig. 1). Residual error is estimated as the difference between the total sum of squared deviations and the sum of squared deviations due to the effects of the individual parameters. However, the contribution of the residual error is <2.0% for all cases; thus, this error can be ignored without losing any significant information from the observed results [26]. Fig. 2 shows the parity plot between the predicted and observed experimental values of XS. The predicted values match the observed values reasonably well within the range of experimental conditions, with R 2 >98%. In addition, the prediction points in Fig. 2 are evenly distributed about the 45° line. Overall, the plot suggests that the Taguchi analysis is applicable and reliable with a good degree of accuracy over the range of experimental conditions. 3.1.2 Range analysis The change in the mean sulfur-removal conversion (ΔXMean) induced by increasing the level of the reaction parameters from low to high can be estimated quantitatively using range analysis [34]. Table 4 shows the results of range analysis for different catalysts with the parameters ranked based on the obtained ΔXMean values. For the Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, contact time is ranked first, followed by the reaction gas type, reaction temperature, total pressure, sulfur concentration, nitrogen concentration, and finally activation temperature. For the MgO supported catalyst, contact time is again the top-ranking parameter, followed by reaction temperature, total pressure, nitrogen concentration, sulfur concentration, reaction gas type, and activation temperature. 3.2 Kinetic studies Much more data were required for the kinetic studies of the reaction; thus, the Taguchi method was also used as a predictive model (Fig. 2 shows the reliability of this method). The sulfur concentration versus contact time at different temperatures was obtained using this predictive method. The corresponding profile is shown in Fig. 3 for one typical set of experimental conditions (sulfur concentration: 500ppm, reaction gas type: H2, total pressure: 7bar, nitrogen concentration: 0, and activation temperature: 400°C). Similar trends were also obtained for the other cases (plots not shown here). The reaction rate constants were calculated using these concentration profiles and assuming pseudo-first-order reaction rates [35,36]. Fig. 4 shows the Arrhenius plots of the reaction rate constants carried out on two Mo −supported catalysts. Table 5 summarizes the values of the apparent activation energies and pre-exponential factors calculated from the slopes and intercepts in Fig. 4. Unlike the Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the MgO supported catalyst displays two branches in the Arrhenius plots, one descending branch up to 320°C and the other ascending branch above this temperature. Therefore, two activation energies and pre-exponential factors in each case were calculated for this catalyst. 3.3 Effect of pyridine To estimate the extent to which pyridine inhibited (reduced) the overall reaction rate, two extreme conditions were studied: the best conditions (sulfur concentration: 750ppm, total pressure: 7bar, reaction gas type: H2, activation temperature: 400°C) and the worst conditions (sulfur concentration: 500ppm, total pressure: 1bar, reaction gas type: N2, activation temperature: 400°C). The values of the pseudo-first-order reaction rate constants along with the apparent activation energies and pre-exponential factors relative to those values in the absence of pyridine are summarized in Table 6 . 3.4 XPS results It is widely accepted that supported Mo-species are present on the surface of HDS catalysts in a highly dispersed state. Consequently, bulk characterization techniques are not adequate to determine the chemical state of Mo-based catalysts. XPS provides interesting information concerning the state of highly dispersed catalysts and has been used in similar studies to determine the extent and state of Mo sulfidation in the presence [37,38] and absence [39,40] of promoters over different supports [40,41]. The XPS spectra of Mo (3d), S (2p) and O (1s) were obtained for the activated and the non-activated catalysts (Fig. 5 ). According to the S (2p) spectra of the catalysts, a sharp sulfur peak appears for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst after activation; in contrast, there is no trace of sulfide phase in the case of the activated MgO supported catalyst and only a minor amount of sulfated phase was detected. The Mo (3d) spectra reveals nearly the same oxidation state for both non-activated catalysts [40]. However, the trend is not the same for activated catalysts; activation reduces most of the Mo species on γ-Al2O3 to Mo+IV, while the MgO supported catalyst not only shows no such reduction, but also shows extra oxidation compared with the non-activated counterparts. Activation reduced both the amount and binding energy of the O (1s) spectra of the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst; however, both of these increased for the activated MgO supported catalyst. The migration and consumption of loosely bonded bulk oxygen atoms with under-coordinated Mo atoms under highly reducing conditions on the MgO support could be a reason for such extra oxidation. 3.5 FT-IR results On activated catalysts, FT-IR spectroscopy of DBT adsorption was performed to qualitatively estimate the adsorption strength of the reactants with temperature (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary data). The spectra reveals a relatively strong adsorption on the MgO supported catalyst that decreases gradually with temperature until only traces of DBT are present at 350°C. Conversely, in the case of the activated γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, no sign of adsorption is present. Due to the similarity of the patterns at different temperatures, only the profile at 200°C is shown for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst. Moreover, FT-IR spectroscopy of the spent catalysts was performed to characterize the presence of specific chemical groups. The spectra shows that the MgO supported catalyst has a distinct SH stretching vibration band at around 2500–2600cm−1 [42] at lower temperatures; the band decreases slightly with temperature and completely dissipates at 350°C (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary data). In addition, the reduction in sharpness of the band around 3600cm−1 along with the broadening of the band above 3000cm−1 with temperature indicates the disappearance of SH groups and a rise in the concentration of OH groups. In contrast, for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, the temperature leads to an increase in the intensity of SH groups around 3600cm−1; however, because of their lower concentrations, the weak SH stretching vibration bands around 2500–2600cm−1 are not distinguishable. 4 Discussion 4.1 Effect of reaction parameters on desulfurization reaction 4.1.1 Contact time The findings show that contact time was the most significant parameter in the desulfurization reaction for both catalysts (Table 4); (as expected) XS increases with contact time (Figs. 1 and 3). 4.1.2 Activation temperature The results show the positive effect of activation temperature on sulfur conversion on γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts (Fig. 1). A similar trend was previously reported and attributed to the generation of the most effective type 2 MoS2 phases [28]. In contrast, for the MgO supported catalyst, the sulfur conversion is independent of the activation temperature. The XPS results shown in Fig. 5 reveal that this observation is attributable to the non-reducibility and, consequently, the non-sulfidability of the Mo species on the MgO support. The XRD experiments were used to study the different specimens created on the Mo/MgO catalyst (Fig. S3 in the Supplementary data). The formation of the MgMoO4 phase over the MgO support can be observed. Thermodynamic calculations were also carried out using HSC Chemistry 6.0 software to study the ΔG diagrams (Ellingham) for the relative stability of various oxides in the MoMgO system, which confirmed the tendency of Mo species toward MgMoO4 formation (Fig. S4 in the Supplementary data). Accordingly, it is assumed that irreducible tetrahedrally coordinated Mo6+ in well-dispersed MgMoO4 domains [43,44] are the active species for the desulfurization reaction (the results in the current study confirm this assumption). 4.1.3 Reaction gas type The catalytic desulfurization of sulfur-containing compounds is usually performed in the presence of hydrogen gas. The present study introduced the effect of the reaction gas type and the use of nitrogen instead of hydrogen as a new variable. The results of performing the reaction without hydrogen might reveal the possible promoting effects of hydrogen in the desulfurization reaction depending on the catalyst type. The results in Fig. 1 show that, while the use of hydrogen improves the desulfurization reaction, reaction progress is also possible in the absence of hydrogen (Fig. S5 in the Supplementary data). The promoting effect of hydrogen may be interpreted from three points of view. First, hydrogen can take part directly in the reaction by removing the sulfur atoms in the form of H2S gas. It is believed that the adsorption of DBT on the catalyst weakens the sulfurcarbon bonds [45] and the broken sulfur atoms, similar to pyrolysis of some organic sulfur compounds [46], may be removed in the form of S2 gas. Thus, the presence of hydrogen may lead to removal of the sulfur compounds in the form of H2S gas, which is thermodynamically preferable. Hydrogenation of organic sulfur compounds also plays a role in the promoting effect. Previously, it has been reported that hydrogenation (or partial hydrogenation) of some organic sulfur compounds increases the electron density over sulfur heteroatoms, which increases the sulfur conversion [47]. Therefore, the stronger positive effect of hydrogen on desulfurization reactions over the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst compared to the MgO supported catalyst can originate from its higher hydrogenation capability on DBT (Fig. 1). The third promoting effect of hydrogen is a consequence of its ability to alter and increase the adsorption of organic sulfur components. This behavior is presented in more detail in section 4.1.5 and is known as positive lateral interactions [48]. 4.1.4 Temperature The temperature of a reaction system is an important variable because of its strong effect on reaction rates. The Arrhenius plots were used to calculate the activation energy of the reaction. The activation energies for desulfurization reactions on the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst (Table 5) are positive, in line with previously published results (for example [15]). However, they are negative on the MgO supported catalyst at lower temperatures before becoming positive at higher temperatures. The negative values are a little surprising as positive values are expected for activation energies. Actually, the activation energy derived from the Arrhenius plots represents the apparent and not the real activation energy of the rate-determining step. The relationship between the apparent and true activation energy is represented by Eq. (2) as follows: (2) E app = Δ H ads . reactants + E true + E diss . H 2 + Δ H des . where the terms represent, from left to right, the apparent activation energy, the heat of adsorption of the reactants, the true activation energy, the H2 dissociation energy, and the heat of desorption. Therefore, negative apparent activation energy may be obtained when the adsorption energies of the reactants are large enough. The FT-IR results for DBT adsorption (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary data) reveal a strong adsorption at lower temperatures on the MgO supported catalyst. The adsorption becomes weaker with increases in temperature. Therefore, the heat of adsorption (which is predominant at lower temperatures) becomes negligible at higher temperatures, where the negative activation energies are replaced with positive values. In contrast, no strong adsorption occurs on the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, resulting in positive activation energies across the entire temperature range. 4.1.5 Sulfur concentration and pressure The results in Fig. 1 reveal the positive effect of both the sulfur concentration and total pressure in sulfur conversion, in line with the findings in the literature [17,19]. Sulfur concentration and total pressure also influences the kinetic parameters (Table 5). In the descending branch of the MgO supported catalyst, the increase in the concentration of the reactants and the total pressure give rise to absolute values of apparent activation energies. This could be attributed to the presence of positive lateral interaction between the reactants, further strengthening the adsorption [48]. However, in the case of the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst and the ascending branch of the MgO supported catalyst, in which the effect of adsorption is negligible, the positive lateral interactions may hinder desorption and consequently give rise to the apparent activation energies [48]. These interactions are more significant in the presence of hydrogen as the reaction gas, which may be attributed to the presence of stronger positive lateral interactions between the organic sulfur compounds and hydrogen. However, this trend is not the same across the entire temperature range and is more significant for both catalysts at the highest temperature (350°C), with a more profound effect at the lowest temperature for the MgO supported catalyst. This can be caused by the extent of dissociated hydrogen atoms at higher temperatures for both catalysts and by the presence of SH groups at lower temperatures for the MgO supported catalyst (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary data). 4.1.6 Nitrogen concentration Nitrogen-containing compounds, especially alkaline compounds, are known to be poisons in terms of their inhibitory effect on desulfurization reactions [29]. Specifically, they engage in competitive adsorption and consequently decrease the reaction rate. According to the results in Table 6, although inhibition was observed for both catalysts, it is more pronounced with the MgO supported catalyst. The fact that the adsorption is stronger with the MgO supported catalyst may be one reason for this increased relative inhibition. For both catalysts and in the absence of hydrogen, decreased inhibition was observed with temperature increases. This trend is the consequence of the diminished adsorption of nitrogen-containing compounds with temperature increases. Changing the reaction gas type to hydrogen not only enhances the inhibition effect of pyridine, but also alters the temperature-dependent behavior. This may be caused by the increased poisoning effect of pyridine upon reaction with hydrogen atoms due to the formation of pyridinium ions, as has been reported previously [49]. In addition, at higher temperatures the growing concentration of dissociated hydrogen atoms gives rise to the probability of the formation of pyridinium ions. Taken together, the increase in efficiency of these inhibitors may compensate their quantitative reduction at higher temperatures. This is the case for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst and the ascending branch of the MgO supported catalyst. For the descending branch of the MgO supported catalyst in the presence of hydrogen, the situation is completely different; namely, the inhibition decreases as temperature increases. The created SH groups can provide pyridine molecules with hydrogen, which can lead to a more profound inhibition effect attributable to pyridine for this catalyst with the presence of hydrogen at lower temperatures. Accordingly, the decrease in inhibition with increasing temperature can be related to the lowering of the concentration of SH groups over the MgO supported catalyst on the descending branch. 4.2 Compensation phenomena and transition state theory A particular interrelationship was observed between A and E values: within a group of comparable rate processes, the effective influence of a change of one Arrhenius parameter is offset by a corresponding (compensatory) change of the other. This behavior (the compensation effect) is usually expressed by the following equation: (3) Ln A = B + e E where B and e are constants, characteristic of the particular group of reactions to which the relationship applies. Obedience to Eq. (3) has been reported in the literature for many groups of heterogeneous rate processes [50,51]. The compensation effect is a general, or at least widely occurring, characteristic feature of surface processes rather than an exceptional phenomenon requiring an exceptional explanation [52]. Compensation can be shown when either a series of related reactions is studied on a given catalyst or when a given reaction is followed on a series of congruent catalysts [53]. The apparent activation energies ( E app ) and the pre-exponential factors (A) in Table 5 for the catalysts are given in a compensation plot (Fig. 6 ). All data sets show a linear relation between E app and LnA, with high correlation coefficients. Moreover, such a linear relationship for each data set may be associated with the operation of the same reaction mechanism or intermediate [52]. According to our unpublished results, different Mo phases that emerge with the use of different supports result in different reaction pathways. Accordingly, the observed discrepancies in the slopes between the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst and the descending branch of the MgO supported catalyst can be attributed to different reaction mechanisms. However, the slope of the ascending branch on the MgO supported catalyst lies between the other two data sets, with a tendency toward the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst. The similar responses to some variables between the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst and the ascending branch of the MgO supported catalyst (see Section 4.1) further prove the similarity in the reaction mechanisms present in these two cases. Transition state theory was used to evaluate the reaction mechanisms on the supported catalysts. Compensation between the Arrhenius parameters may find its origin in a relation between the enthalpies and entropies of activation. The fundamental equation of transition state theory gives the rate constant as Eq. (4): (4) k TST = k b T h exp Δ S ≠ R exp ( − Δ H ≠ RT ) ) (5) A TST = k b T h exp ( Δ S ≠ R ) where kb is the Boltzmann’s constant, h is the Planck’s constant, T is the absolute temperature, Δ S ≠ is the entropy of activation, Δ H ≠ is the enthalpy of activation, R is the gas constant, and A TST is the pre-exponential factor [48]. Δ S ≠ and Δ H ≠ must be supplied for the reaction to reach the transition state. For a catalyzed reaction, the pre-exponential factor A equates to the first two terms on the right-hand side; consequently, LnA is proportional to Δ S ≠ . As Eq. (5) shows, a gain in entropy in going from the reactants to the transition state results in a large pre-exponential factor and increases the rate of reaction. This situation corresponds to partition functions of vibration, rotation, and/or translation that are higher in the transition state than in the ground state of the reactant; this is often called a loose transition state. An alternative viewpoint is that the transition state provides more energy levels that can be occupied at a given temperature than does the ground state. The converse situation, in which the entropy of the transition state is lower than that of the ground state of the reactant, can also occur. In this case, the transition state is tight because rotations, vibration, or motion of the activated complex are more restricted than in the ground state of the reactant. According to the LnA values in Table 5, for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst and the ascending branch of the MgO supported catalyst, the entropy of activation increases along with increases in DBT concentrations and pressure, while that of the descending branch of the MgO supported catalyst decreases. Therefore, the activation over the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst is in loose transition state mode, while that of the MgO supported catalyst at lower temperatures is in tight transition state mode, which becomes a loose transition state mode at higher temperatures as the mobility of the reactants increases. The similarity in transition state modes seems to be the reason for the similarity in reaction mechanisms between the ascending branch of the MgO supported catalyst and the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst. 5 Conclusions In this study, the Taguchi method facilitated the evaluation of the parametric effects on the reaction mechanism of DBT desulfurization reactions over two supported Mo-based catalysts. The order of significance of the parameters on sulfur removal efficiency over the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst is as follows: contact time>reaction gas type>temperature>pressure>sulfur concentration>nitrogen concentration>activation temperature. The order for the MgO supported catalyst is slightly different and is as follows: contact time>temperature>pressure>nitrogen concentration>sulfur concentration>reaction gas type>activation temperature. Increases in temperature accelerate the reaction on the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst. However, the reaction decelerates as temperature increases at lower temperatures on the MgO supported catalyst and accelerates at higher temperatures. The compensatory plots reveal a change in reaction mechanism with temperature on the MgO supported catalyst that approximates the reaction mechanism on the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst at higher temperatures. Transition state theory showed that the tight activation transition state mode is replaced with the loose mode at higher temperatures on the MgO supported catalyst, whereas for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, the loose mode prevails across the entire temperature range. There are also some temperature-dependent concentrations of the SH and OH functional groups at the surface of the catalyst, increasing the poisoning effect of pyridine through formation of pyridinium ions. The inhibition effect changes with temperature and catalyst type, in line with the concentration variations of the functional groups. In the absence of hydrogen, where there are no hydrogen-containing functional groups, the inhibition is negligible and declines with temperature due to the weakening of the adsorption. coredata.dc:description: This study uses the Taguchi method to evaluate the impact of support on the catalytic behavior of Mo/MgO and Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts through the parametric effects on the kinetics of dibenzothiophene desulfurization reaction. The parameters studied were contact time, temperature, activation temperature, reaction gas type, sulfur concentration, pressure, and nitrogen concentration. Some discrepancies existed in the order of significance of the reaction parameters between the two catalysts. The compensation phenomena revealed a change in the reaction mechanism with temperature for Mo/MgO catalyst that approximates that of Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at higher temperatures. Transition state theory showed that for the Mo/MgO catalyst, the tight activation transition state mode is replaced with a loose mode at higher temperatures, whereas for the Mo/γ-Al2O3catalyst, the loose mode prevails across the entire temperature range studied. Furthermore, some temperature-dependent concentrations of SH and OH functional groups were detected at the catalyst surface, profoundly influencing the adsorption of the reactants and the inhibition effect of pyridine.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of support on the catalytic behavior of Mo/γ-Al2O3 and Mo/MgO catalysts on the desulfurization reaction
